bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Harry N. Sykes was born in Starkville, Mississippi on April 1, 1927, to Marie Hall Sykes and P.K. Sykes. His family moved to Maywood, Illinois, where Sykes graduated high school in 1948. He attended Kentucky State University on a basketball and track scholarship, graduating in 1952. Later, Sykes completed a Master's degree in mathematics from the University of Minnesota. From 1952-1954, he played on the Harlem Globetrotters professional basketball team. From 1954 to 1962, Sykes taught mathematics at Dunbar High School. In 1963, he was elected to the Lexington City Council, the first African American councilman for the city. Sykes also served as mayor pro-tem from 1967-1969. He founded the Lexington Fayette County Urban League in 1968, serving as president from 1968-1972. In 1971, Sykes ran unsuccessfully for Mayor of Lexington, narrowly losing to Foster Pettit. He served as acting city manager from 1972 to 1974, and as acting chief administrative officer for the Lexington Fayette Urban County Government from 1974-1975. Sykes held a variety of other positions throughout his professional life including insurance salesman (1964-1969), business development officer for Second National Bank (1970-1972), realtor (1981-1992), and a contract compliance officer with the Frankfort, Kentucky, Department of Finance. He was also heavily involved with the Historical Pleasant Green Baptist Church in Lexington and other community boards and commissions.
Sykes married Geraldine Higgins Sykes and had five children. He passed away on November 28, 2012, at the age of 85.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Harry N. Sykes papers (dated 1880-2012, undated; 10.1 cubic feet; 8 boxes, 2 flat boxes, 21 photograph boxes) comprise correspondence, newspaper clippings and articles, pamphlets, publications, newsletters, notes, forms, lists, and photographs that document the life and work of Harry N. Sykes. The collection is arranged into six series.

The City of Lexington series comprises correspondence, pamphlets, memos and reports, publications, and clippings related to education, politics, city government, local businesses and organizations, and local water control in Lexington and Fayette County.

The Historic Pleasant Green Baptist Church series comprises primarily programs, publications, and correspondence related to the Church and its operations. Also includes correspondence, notes, and reports related to Simmons Bible College and various community events and programs.

The Personal series comprises correspondence, programs, notes, newsletters, publications, lists, and clippings related to Sykes' education at Dunbar High School and Kentucky State University, political leanings and activities, personal relationships and family papers, and daily life.
The Photographs series comprises assorted photographs sorted into three bulk categories including assorted friends and family, events and publicity, and trips and travel.
The Publicity series comprises primarily newspaper clippings, articles, ephemera, and pamphlets related to Sykes' careers and public life, including his tenure with the Harlem Globetrotters.
The Real Estate series comprises correspondence, newsletters, forms, notes, and clippings related to Sykes' real estate business. Also included are signs advertising Sykes' business and properties.
